integrations_researched.name: Tailwind CSS

api_patterns.initialization: Configured via @theme inline {} in CSS files
key_functions: Responsive breakpoints: sm:, md:, lg:, xl:, 2xl:
Mobile-first utilities: all utilities work mobile-first

mobile_specific.mobile_first_approach: Unprefixed utilities target mobile, prefix for larger screens

gotchas: Tailwind v4 uses CSS variables (@theme) instead of JS config file
Must use rem units for breakpoints, not px (causes ordering issues)
Mobile-first means base styles apply to mobile, then override with md:, lg:, etc.
Container queries require @container class on parent element

integrations_researched.name: Radix UI

api_patterns.initialization: Import primitive components and compose with custom styles

mobile_specific.touch_support: Slider component supports keyboard and touch input
mobile_specific.ios_fixes: Recent updates prevent outside pointer events triggering on touch devices
mobile_specific.focus_management: Ensures iOS Safari focuses first focusable element consistently
mobile_specific.aria_support: Full WAI-ARIA compliance for screen readers

gotchas: Components are unstyled primitives - styling is your responsibility
Touch interactions may need custom touch-target sizing (min 44x44px recommended)
Tooltips on mobile: consider using onClick instead of hover for better UX
Dialog components trap focus - test on mobile screen readers
Some hover states don't translate to mobile - implement active/pressed states

integrations_researched.name: React

imports: import { useState, useEffect, useCallback, useMemo } from 'react'
import { use } from 'react' // React 19 new API
import { useTransition } from 'react' // Enhanced in React 19
key_functions: useOptimistic() - Optimistic UI updates for mobile
use() - Read resources in render (Context, Promises)

performance_patterns: Use useTransition for non-urgent updates on slower mobile devices
Leverage useOptimistic for instant feedback on mobile networks
React Compiler handles memoization automatically - less useMemo/useCallback needed
Suspense boundaries for code splitting and lazy loading
mobile_specific.touch_events: Standard browser touch events (touchstart, touchmove, touchend)
mobile_specific.viewport_considerations: Use viewport meta tag and CSS viewport units

gotchas: React 19 automatic memoization may change behavior if migrating from React 18
useOptimistic requires async transitions - different pattern than useState
Touch events don't automatically prevent default - may need to handle scrolling
Mobile browsers may delay touch events by 300ms - consider touch-action CSS
React 19.2 includes fixes for Safari mobile issues

integrations_researched.name: Vite

imports: const Component = lazy(() => import('./Component')) // Code splitting

mobile_specific.code_splitting: Use dynamic import() for bundles > 30kb to reduce initial load
mobile_specific.chunk_optimization: Configure rollup.output.manualChunks to split vendor bundles

gotchas: Code splitting for bundles < 30kb may slow down app (too many network requests)
Dynamic imports create async boundaries - wrap with Suspense
manualChunks configuration requires understanding dependency graph
Mobile networks: prioritize critical path, defer non-essential chunks
Vite dev server may not reflect production bundle size - always test production build

integrations_researched.name: CSS Viewport Units (dvh, svh, lvh)

key_functions: dvh - Dynamic viewport height (adjusts with mobile browser toolbars)
svh - Small viewport height (with toolbars expanded)
lvh - Large viewport height (with toolbars collapsed)

use_cases.dvh: Best for full-height sections that adapt to mobile browser UI
use_cases.svh: Ensures content visible when address bar is expanded
use_cases.lvh: Maximum viewport height (equivalent to traditional vh)
use_cases.fallback: Provide vh fallback for older browsers

gotchas: Traditional vh doesn't account for mobile browser toolbars - use dvh instead
dvh changes dynamically as user scrolls (address bar shows/hides)
svh is safest for preventing content cutoff on initial load
Not all browsers support dvh/svh/lvh - always provide vh fallback
Layout shifts may occur with dvh as toolbars appear/disappear - test thoroughly
iOS Safari had issues with viewport units in older versions - use modern units

optional_integrations.name: @use-gesture/react
optional_integrations.description: Advanced touch gesture library for React web apps
optional_integrations.when_to_use: If thread builder or templates require drag/swipe/pinch gestures

imports: import { useDrag, useGesture, usePinch, useWheel } from '@use-gesture/react'

optional_integrations.recommendation: Consider only if existing touch events are insufficient for thread builder drag-and-drop on mobile

recommendations: 1. Use Tailwind's mobile-first approach: Write base styles for mobile, then use md:, lg: prefixes for larger screens
2. Replace any 100vh with 100dvh for mobile-friendly full-height sections (with vh fallback)
3. Ensure touch targets are minimum 44x44px for comfortable tapping (Radix components may need custom sizing)
4. Test Radix Dialog, Tooltip, and Toggle components on actual mobile devices for touch interaction
5. Implement code splitting for routes/features to optimize mobile network performance
6. Use useOptimistic hook for instant feedback on mobile networks (e.g., tweet scoring)
7. Add touch-action CSS property to prevent unintended scrolling during interactions
8. Test in both portrait and landscape orientations on various screen sizes
9. Consider @use-gesture/react only if thread builder needs complex drag gestures beyond native touch events
10. Add viewport meta tag: <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1">

layout: Responsive grid/flex layouts with Tailwind breakpoints
Stack columns vertically on mobile (flex-col md:flex-row pattern)
Appropriate spacing and padding for mobile (p-4 md:p-6 lg:p-8)
Safe areas for mobile notches/home indicators
typography: Readable font sizes on small screens (text-sm md:text-base)
Appropriate line height for mobile reading
Avoid horizontal scrolling for text content
interactions: Hover states replaced with active/pressed states on mobile
Prevent zoom on input focus (font-size: 16px minimum)
performance: Code split routes and heavy components
Lazy load images and non-critical assets
Optimize bundle size for mobile networks
testing: Test various screen sizes (iPhone SE to iPad)

strengths: Tailwind CSS v4 provides excellent mobile-first utilities out of the box
Radix UI components are accessible and have some mobile touch support
React 19 offers performance hooks (useOptimistic, useTransition) beneficial for mobile
Vite enables efficient code splitting for mobile performance
Modern CSS viewport units (dvh, svh, lvh) have good browser support
gaps: No explicit touch gesture library (may not be needed - evaluate during implementation)
No viewport meta tag verification (check index.html)
No touch-action CSS utilities configured (can be added to Tailwind theme)
No performance monitoring for mobile networks (consider adding)
